metadata.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, Madhya Pradesh and Bhopal v. Vyas Dotiwala

facts.text: In or about July 1943, when considerable difficulty was being felt about cloth, the Deputy Commissioner, Amraoti, evolved a scheme to solve that difficulty.

Under the scheme, Kisanlal Vyas and the firm Edulji Framji Dotiwala (assessees as association of persons) undertook to finance the scheme without charging any interest or profit and were appointed as financiers and distributors of standard cloth for Amraoti town, camp and certain interior areas.
Assessees agreed to open an account in the Imperial Bank of India to finance purchases of cloth; orders placed by Government with mills.
On arrival of consignment, assessees to pay Deputy Commissioner value of consignment plus 6-1/4% of ex-mill price; consignment checked and delivered to assessees on receipt.
Deputy Commissioner to pay assessees 4-1/2% of ex-mill price for contingent expenses (not to exceed 3%).

Cloth distributed in Amraoti through shop opened by assessees and in interiors through Tehsildars with Patils; distribution under control of Deputy Commissioner who was responsible to assessees for sale proceeds from Tehsildars.
Deputy Commissioner to decide sale price and entitled buyers; out of sale proceeds, pay assessees advances made.

Para 14 of scheme: 'Profits resulting from the scheme shall be utilised for such charitable purposes as may be decided on by the Deputy Commissioner in consultation with the advisory committee appointed to supervise the scheme.'
Books of assessees showed Rs. 34,737/- profits for 1945-46 and Rs. 17,682/- for 1946-47.
Assessment years concerned: 1945-46 and 1946-47; separate assessments consolidated before Tribunal and Supreme Court.
Income-tax Officer assessed assessees on profits; assessees contended exemption under s.4(3)(i-a); rejected.
Appellate Assistant Commissioner confirmed ITO order.
Before Tribunal, assessees objected: (1) not their income, (2) exempt u/s.4(3)(i-a) per letter dated January 22, 1947; Tribunal held not their income, set aside assessments.

Tribunal referred u/s.66(1): 'Whether on the facts of this case any income accrued to Messrs. Vyas and Dotiwala as the result of their associating themselves as financiers in the scheme for the distribution of standard cloth and, if so whether such income was assessable in their hands.'
Nagpur High Court answered question in negative on December 8, 1953, holding no receipt or deemed receipt u/s.4.
Appeal by special leave to Supreme Court; respondents did not appear.

legal_issues.text: Whether on the facts of this case any income accrued to Messrs. Vyas and Dotiwala as the result of their associating themselves as financiers in the scheme for the distribution of standard cloth and, if so whether such income was assessable in their hands.
Whether the profits were exempt under s.4(3)(i-a) of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922.

petitioner_arguments.text: High Court failed to appreciate real question: not whether income received or deemed received, but whether income accrued and formed income of assessees.
Tribunal wrong: assessees worked scheme producing profits; control by Deputy Commissioner does not prevent it being business by assessees; DC guarantee indicates assessees as owners.
Assessees' alternative claim for exemption u/s.4(3)(i-a) implies they carried on business.
Para 14 contemplates profits belonging to assessees, to be devoted to charity; if Government's, no need for provision.

court_reasoning.text: Agrees with Solicitor-General: question is whether profits formed income of assessees, not mere receipt.
court_reasoning.key_observation: High Court judgment criticized for misunderstanding question.

court_reasoning.text: Undisputed assessees worked scheme producing profits; DC control does not prevent it being business by assessees; they agreed to do business in certain manner.
court_reasoning.key_observation: DC guarantee to assessees for Tehsildars' payments indicates assessees as owners.

court_reasoning.text: Assessees' exemption claim implies business; para 14 shows profits theirs, devoted to charity by agreement.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Profits do not cease to be income because devoted to charity.

court_reasoning.text: No bar in scheme to making profits; liable to tax whether agreed not to make profits or not; no evidence assessees paid out profits to charity.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Profits made by assessees are taxable.

court_reasoning.text: No exemption u/s.4(3)(i-a): scheme not carried on behalf of religious/charitable institution.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Once profits made by assessees, how used immaterial.

holdings.text: Profits were income which accrued to assessees and assessable to income-tax.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Income-tax Act, 1922
statutes_cited.relevance: Charging section s.4 for accrual of income; exemption under s.4(3)(i-a) rejected; reference under s.66(1)

outcome.summary: Supreme Court allowed the appeal by special leave, answered the referred question in the affirmative, holding profits accrued to and assessable in hands of assessees, not exempt under s.4(3)(i-a).
outcome.relief_granted: Reversal of High Court judgment; assessments upheld implicitly.

key_quotes.text: "Profits resulting from the scheme shall be utilised for such charitable purposes as may be decided on by the Deputy Commissioner in consultation with the advisory committee."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Para 14 of scheme shows profits belonged to assessees.

key_quotes.text: "The profits belonged to the assessees and hence the necessity for this agreement so that the assessees might be made to spend them on charity."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key reasoning that profits were assessees' income.

key_quotes.text: "If they chose to agree by para. 14 to devote the profits to charity, that was their business the profits made by them would not change their character and cease to be the assessees income because they agreed to devote their income to charity."
key_quotes.speaker: court
